Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: Investigations of Gravity Wave Coupling Between the Mesosphere and Thermosphere in the Southern Hemisphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to investigate the occurrence, propagation characteristics, and coupling processes of atmospheric gravity waves in the Earth's atmosphere, from the troposphere up to the mesosphere and lower thermosphere, at Southern mid-latitudes. A multi-wavelength all-sky imager currently resides at the Mount John Observatory in New Zealand and will be used to record meospheric gravity wave activity. A second imager will be installed at a field station further to the south of Mount John, at Lauder, Otago, to provide greater coverage during DEEPWAVE and to minimize poor weather conditions at either location during the winter campaign period. The Mount John instrument is co-located with other ground-based instrumentation relevant to mesospheric and thermospheric observations. The co-located multi-diagnostic measurements will consist of mesospheric and thermospheric winds and temperatures obtained by two Fabry-Perot spectrometers and mesospheric wind profiles obtained by a meteor radar system, electron density profiles from an ionosonde, and SABER temperature and OH emission profiles.
These measurements will also contribute to the DEEPWAVE field project which will take place in New Zealand in June-July 2014. Data will be disseminated via a website at Boston University and the CEDAR and MADRIGAL databases. The project will be carried out in collaboration with scientists from New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for NSF award ATM-1343097

 

CEDAR: Investigations of Gravity Wave Coupling Between the

Mesosphere and Thermosphere in the Southern Hemisphere

 

This proposal had several goals. Firstly, it sought to install a multi-spectral all-sky imaging system at the NIWA Lauder station in Otago, New Zealand in order to provide ground-based optical observations of gravity waves during the NOAA/NSF DEEPWAVE campaign during June-July 2014. The DEEPWAVE mission involved a number of research flights to investigate the generation and time evolution of wave activity in the earth’s atmosphere over New Zealand. The international campaign involved over 100 scientists from the United States, New Zealand, Germany, Australia, the United Kingdom utilizing a large number of different research instrumentation onboard the aircraft and distributed about New Zealand.  

Gravity waves are buoyancy oscillations that occur commonly throughout the atmosphere and oceans. They are an extremely important mechanism for the transport of energy and momentum throughout the atmosphere. Societally, gravity waves are an important component to understanding the general structure and behaviour of the atmosphere and for such things as weather forecasting. Although their origins are generally understood –jet streams, mountain ranges, storm fronts, etc. – the specific details on how they arise, evolve and propagate through the atmosphere is still poorly observed and understood. Hence, a better understanding of the phenomenon will lead to more accurate weather forecasting and climate prediction. A case in point, during one of the DEEPWAVE campaign nights, it was decided not to fly because the atmospheric computer models determined that there would be only weak gravity wave activity. During the night, however, there was a large and extensive gravity wave event recorded in upper mesosphere airglow by several imaging systems. The fact is, current models currently have insufficient data and capabilities to deal effectively with predicting gravity wave activity and its effects. Continued research is required to solve this problem

The Boston University all-sky imager records images of several naturally-occurring airglow layers of neutral hydroxyl, sodium, molecular oxygen and atomic oxygen residing in the 80 to 100 km altitude region during night-time. This region is also known as the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT). Airglow arises from the recombination of neutral species that were broken down due to solar radiation during the daytime hours. The layers are relatively narrow (~10 km thick) and so as waves and other disturbances pass through the layers, they modulate the emission rate and so the layer can be used as dynamical tracers. The height separation of the layers: hydroxyl (OH, ~87 km), sodium (Na, ~90 km), molecular oxygen (O2, ~94 km), and atomic oxygen (O, ~97km) provides a means to sample the vertical structure of the gravity waves.

 

Gravity waves contribute significant amounts of energy and momentum to the MLT region; around 70% and so their generation and propagation characteristics need to be understood. Because of its location in the Southern Ocean, New Zealand is known as a gravity wave “hotspot” and so is an excellent location to study gravity waves from ground level all the way up to the edge of space near 100 km and beyond.
